awd_titl_txt: Catalytic Properties and Coordination Chemistry of Heavier Group 11 and 12 Elements
awd_abstract_narration: The Inorganic, Bioinorganic and Organometallic Chemistry Program supports the research efforts of Professor H. V. Rasika Dias of the University of Texas at Arlington to obtain and study thermally-stable gold and mercury complexes of carbon monoxide, ethylene, acetylene, and other small alkenes and alkynes. Novel, metal-catalyzed, carbon-halogen bond activation processes are also under investigation. Complexes with mercury(II) and gold(I) bonds to small carbon-based, unsaturated molecules are difficult to isolate.  Professor Dias uses certain weakly coordinating anions as supporting ligands or counter anions for the stabilization of such species.  The crystalline solids of these complexes display unusually high thermal and air stability.  They serve as useful catalysts for various transformations, including carbon-halogen bond activation chemistry.  Professor Dias and his group are involved in developing web-based methods for the exchange and dissemination of research results and for the live-delivery of online courses on various aspects of chemistry.  The lecture materials are especially intended for students in foreign academic institutions with faculty shortages.  Professor Dias is active in mentoring K-12 teachers, high school students, and undergraduate researchers with diverse backgrounds.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

Although metals like gold, silver and mercury are renowned for their inertness, under certain conditions, they serve as excellent catalysts for creating useful and more complex molecules from simple substances such as ethylene and acetylene.  The first part of project was focused on uncovering how metals like gold facilitate such chemistry.  Part two concerns developing new and useful reactions mediated by these metals. During the life of the award, we discovered methods to isolate molecules that feature bonds between metal ions like gold and small carbon based molecules like carbon monoxide, olefins and alkynes.  The resulting compounds were investigated completely using X-ray crystallography and various spectroscopic methods. We examined the effect different metals and supporting ligands have on the properties of these species.  We also developed several metal ion chelators based on nitrogen-donors that can serve as good supporting ligands for many types of metal ions.   Such chelators could improve the outcome of reactions mediated by those metals. 
Overall, we have made a number of significant contributions to science ranging from the isolation of novel molecules to discovery of useful catalytic processes important in chemistry.  The new findings were reported in scientific journals and at conferences.  This research was carried out by a truly interdisciplinary and a diverse team. A number of students, including a few from high schools, received training on useful research techniques. Everyone involved learned not only the science but also the importance of team work. There were also several fruitful collaborations with scientists from foreign countries.
